instruction: [INST] Analyze this file to learn MacBook motherboard repair. The 'definitions' section explains key technical terms. The 'threads' section contains real-world repair discussions. Use both sections to understand and learn how to troubleshoot MacBook issues. Posts from username 'larossmann' , 'dukefawks' , and '2informaticos' are posts from trusted experts.[/INST]

definitions.820-00165: What is 820-00165? a LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER.
definitions.Q7706: What is Q7706? Q7706 takes PPBUS_G3H's main 12.6v and sends it through to the backlight circuit. If Q9706 is not allowing PPBUS_G3H through, you will get no voltage on the backlight circuit. Q7706 is a P channel MOSFET, meaning power will flow through it when the voltage on the gate is lower than on the source. Look at pin 3. R7788 takes the 12.6v that is on the source and places it right on pin 3. This will set Q7706 to "off", and not allow it to pass power, as the voltage on the source and the gate are identical..
definitions.EDP_BKLT_EN: What is EDP_BKLT_EN? This is an enable signal. Anytime you see “_EN”, it means when the voltage is high(3.3 volts), whatever it is going to is being turned on or enabled. Here, “EDP_BKLT” which stands for “embedded displayport backlight” is being enabled. This signal usually goes to an LED driver used for creating a power rail for the LCD screen backlight, to tell it to turn on & create this rail. .

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00165</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> Backlight Again
threads.message:
Hello,

Feeling stumped on this one. No backlight. 
Fuse at F7700 OK. <CHIP>U7701</CHIP> backlight driver was shorted to ground.
No voltage getting past <TRANSISTOR>Q7706</TRANSISTOR> at all. Voltage at pin 4 of <TRANSISTOR>Q7706</TRANSISTOR> is 9.83 volts. Pin 3 is at 9.55 volts.
Resistance at <RESISTOR>R7788</RESISTOR> is 300K. <CAPACITOR>C7782</CAPACITOR> is not shorted open. Pins 1,2,5,6 are at 0 volts.

I replaced the backlight driver IC <CHIP>U7701</CHIP>. Figured that <TRANSISTOR>Q7706</TRANSISTOR> was bad and replaced, along with <RESISTOR>R7788</RESISTOR> and <CAPACITOR>C7782</CAPACITOR>. 
Removed <RESISTOR>R7789</RESISTOR> temporarily to isolate the MOSFET and still 0 volts on output.

I am stumped. Voltage on pin 3 should be much lower than pin 4 for the gate to function I believe, but I cant seem to find what I am missing.

Any ideas?

Thanks,

Stefan

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00165</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> Backlight Again
threads.message:
Do you see any image on display????
Voltage on pin 2 and 5 from <TRANSISTOR>Q7707</TRANSISTOR>???

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00165</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> Backlight Again
threads.message:
Oh, right. Display is working.
<TRANSISTOR>Q7707</TRANSISTOR>:
Pin 2 - 3.7 volts
pin 5 - 0 volts

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00165</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> Backlight Again
<LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00165</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> Backlight Again
threads.message:
Well, shoot. Pin # 5 <SIGNAL>EDP_BKLT_EN</SIGNAL> is shorted to ground. 
Removed <TRANSISTOR>Q7707</TRANSISTOR> and retested to be sure.

Pretty sure this is done then.

Cleaning in ultrasonic just in case I am extra lucky, but I doubt it.

Thanks,

Stefan

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00165</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> Backlight Again
threads.message: If it is really shorted you can disconnect the line and tie pin 5 to <SIGNAL>LCD_EN</SIGNAL>
